bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [June 12?, 1902]

div1.p: Reed writes that the shipments are on their way to her. He is leaving for Boston, is looking forward to a reunion with his Cuban colleagues, and concludes with news of Forwood's confirmation.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [June 12?, 1902]
div1.p:
Your darling letter
of Tuesday night has been received
and your Commissary list turned over
to John the driver, who has gone down
to the Barracks for them- Beechner has
orders to pack & ship them up to you
at once- I will leave for Boston
at 4.50 P.M, to-day, and have just come
home to get my valise- I find that
I cannot leave there until Saturday
morning & hence as I could not
reach Baltimore in time for the
Western Maryland, I will probably
spend Saturday in seeing something
of the village & leave there Saturday
evening- Dr Kean, Grable, Gorgas,
& a number of other friends will be
there, so that we ought to have a
very good time- I got a telegram from
Gen. Wood, this afternoon, from West
Point, saying that my presence at the
dinner met the Secretary's warmest
approval- The latter will be there
but I don't know whether he will enter
into sweet converse with me or not, Col. For-
wood has not been confirmed yet, but
nobody seems to think that there will
be any doubt about it- Glad that
your window fasteners are so satis-
factory and that the store-room is in
shape- When you get that “Wilson's” “Ex-
tra dry”, you will be all fixed- much love
to the Ping-Pongers- very warm here- Kisses
& love for my precious babies-
